required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Can Kangarooing Small Babies on the Back of a Mother Keep Them Warm and Stable
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Chest-to-Back Skin-to-Skin Contact on Regulation of Physiological Parameters for Low Birth Weight and/or Premature Infants: a Crossover Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial

collaborator.agency: Adds Continental Institute of Public Health

clinical_study.source: Addis Continental Institute of Public Health

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study was to assess the effectiveness of Kangarooing small babies on the back of a mother

detailed_description.textblock: After the study was explained (risks and benefits) and written informed consent was received from participants, an individually controlled randomized crossover clinical trial was conducted to examine the effectiveness of Chest-to-Back (CB) skin-to-skin contact (SSC) compared with the standard. The trial was done in accordance with the protocol, good clinical practice, and the national regulatory and ethics guideline of Ethiopia (which is in line with the Helsinki declaration).

study_design_info.masking_description: Mothers were masked only for the presence or absence of a sequence in the trial. Hospital staffs, students, and investigators of the study were all blinded to allocation of the intervention. Until the study was finalized, access to the database was restricted to the data manager only

primary_outcome.measure: Change in skin temperature from baseline
primary_outcome.time_frame: : From the start of SSC (0 hour) to end of SSC (2 hours) per day, assessed for three consecutive days
primary_outcome.description: Skin temperature values were recorded every 10 minutes. Including the baseline, the 2 hours intervention would provide 13 measurements. A participant who successfully completed the intervention would have78 measurements; 39 for the treatment arm and 39 for the control arm.

other_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in peripheral arterial oxygen saturation on SCRIP Score
other_outcome.time_frame: From the start of SSC (0 hour) to end of SSC (2 hours) per day, assessed for three consecutive days
other_outcome.description: Stability of the cardio-respiratory system in premature infants (SCRIP) score is a reliable instrument for determining the stability of oxygen saturation (i.e., peripheral arterial oxygen saturation) in premature infants. Possible scores range from 2 (perfect stability= > 90 %) to 0 (sever instability = any falls below 80%)

other_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in heart rate on SCRIP Score
other_outcome.time_frame: From the start of SSC (0 hour) to end of SSC (2 hours) per day, assessed for three consecutive days
other_outcome.description: Possible scores range from 2 (perfect stability= regular) to 0 (sever instability = ＜ 80/min or＞200).

other_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in respiratory rate on SCRIP Score
other_outcome.time_frame: From the start of SSC (0 hour) to end of SSC (2 hours) per day, assessed for three consecutive days
other_outcome.description: Possible scores range from 2 (perfect stability= regular) to 0 (sever instability = Apnea＞ 10, Tachypnea＞ 80/min, fussing/agitation

other_outcome.time_frame: From the start of SSC (0 hour) to end of SSC (2 hours) per day, assessed for three consecutive days.
other_outcome.description: length of sleep was defined by the duration between the time of closed eyes, no crying and no movement to the time that at least one of these 3 indicators is absent

arm_group.description: The participant received CB-SSC for 2 hours per day for three consecutive days
Following a 30 minute washout time, the same participant would continue to receive chest-to-chest (CC) SSC for 2 hours. This was also conducted for three consecutive days

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Neonates with LBW (<2500 grams)
- Born prematurely (< 37 complete weeks of gestation)
Exclusion Criteria:
- less than 35 weeks of gestation on the day of enrollment to trial
- Malformations or birth disabilities
- Dependent on oxygen or IV fluid
- Any disorder that was deemed necessary for exclusion by the investigator.

facility.name: Adds Continental Institute of Public Health

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Addis Continental Institute of Public Health
responsible_party.investigator_title: MSc, PhD candidate, and lecturer at Arsi University College of Health Sciences, Ethiopia

patient_data.ipd_description: Upon a reasonable request, the investigators can offer access to the datasets used and/or analyzed. This can be available from the PI (principal investigator)
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: Possibly after six months the data will be available.
